Yet as the S&P 500 pushed to fresh records this week, investors were again forced to confront a painful reality: Keeping pace with the market has largely meant owning little else.

title: California Faces More Flooding in Latest Wave of Heavy Rains
summary: California is facing another day of heavy rain and risks of flash floods, prompting officials to warn about the dangers for road travel in this busy holiday period.

title: China’s Solar Power Additions Rise to Six-Month High in November
summary: China’s solar installations in November surged to the highest in six months, extending an end-of-year recovery.

title: China Vows to Prevent Yuan’s Exchange Rate From ‘Overshooting’
summary: China vowed to prevent the yuan’s exchange rate from overshooting, sending yet another clear signal of its intention to slow the currency’s appreciation.

title: China Slaps Symbolic Sanctions on US Firms Over Taiwan Arms Sale
summary: China announced largely symbolic sanctions against 20 US defense companies and 10 executives, signaling its anger over Washington’s latest arms sales to Taiwan while stopping short of a broader escalation.

title: China Starts State-Backed Venture Funds to Support Tech Startups
summary: China has officially launched a national venture capital fund and three large regional funds, together worth billions of dollars, as part of a push to foster home-grown tech champions and improve investment efficiency.

title: Coforge Buys Encora at $2.35 Billion EV in All-Stock Deal
summary: Indian technology services provider Coforge Ltd. agreed to buy Encora at an enterprise value of $2.35 billion in an all-stock deal, adding artificial intelligence, data and product engineering expertise.

title: Coinbase Says Former Agent Arrested In India Over Exchange Hack
summary: Coinbase Global Inc. Chief Executive Officer Brian Armstrong said that a former customer service agent for the largest US crypto exchange was arrested in India, months after hackers bribed customer service representatives to gain access to customer information.

title: Copper Hits Record in China, Jumps in New York on Supply Concern
summary: Copper surged to a record in Shanghai and rallied in New York, adding to substantial annual gains as investors bet on tighter global supplies in 2026, while also pricing in the impact of a weaker US dollar.

title: Dollar Caps Worst Week Since June With Focus on Data Ahead
summary: A Bloomberg gauge of the dollar posted its worst week since June as traders looked to data due early next month to confirm expectations for further Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts in 2026.

title: Emerging-Market Stocks, Currencies Add to Rally in Quiet Session
summary: Emerging-market assets added to their recent advances on Friday amid thin holiday trading, as investor sentiment remained bullish heading into the year-end.

title: FaZe Clan Influencers Exit Over Contract Dispute With New Owner
summary: The future of the popular influencer group FaZe Clan is in flux once again after several members announced their departures this week following failed contract talks with new management.

title: Fed Data Show December Surge in 10-Year Treasury Delivery Fails
summary: Delivery fails involving 10-year Treasury notes surged to the highest level in eight years this month, a result of the Federal Reserve’s move to shrink its bond portfolio since 2022.

title: Israel Seals Recognition Deal with Breakaway Somalia Region

title: Japan Eyes Record Defense Spending as GDP, Yen Stretch 2% Goal

title: Japan FSA Said to Boost Watch of Regional Bank Property Lending
summary: Japan’s Financial Services Agency is stepping up monitoring of regional banks that lend heavily to the booming real estate sector to make sure risks are under control, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Japan Plans to Reduce Sales of Super-Long Government Bonds
summary: Japan plans to reduce sales of government bonds during the fiscal year starting in April, focusing on cuts to super-long debt.

title: Japan Sees First Primary Balance Surplus in 28 Years Next Year

summary: Japan’s industry ministry is set to nearly quadruple its budgeted support for cutting-edge semiconductors and artificial intelligence development to about ¥1.23 trillion ($7.9 billion) for the fiscal year starting in April.

title: Larry Ellison, Not Elon Musk, Was The Tech Titan Who Defined 2025
summary: When the year began, a billionaire with close ties to the White House was a lock for the most newsworthy tech titan of 2025. But 12 chaotic months later, Larry Ellison, not Elon Musk, can justifiably lay claim to the title.

title: Latin American Central Banker Starts Crusade Against the Dollar
summary: Uruguay’s central bank chief wants to convince savers in one of Latin America’s most dollarized nations that their love affair with the US currency is bad for both the economy and their pocketbooks.

title: Lebanon Advances Law Aimed at Freeing Up Trapped Bank Deposits

title: Malaysia Fines Ex-PM Najib $2.8 Billion for 1MDB, Adds Jail Time

title: New York State Reports Record Number of Weekly Flu Cases
summary: New York State is seeing the highest number of influenza cases ever recorded in a single week, the health department said on Friday.

title: Palm Oil Hits Two-Week High on Increased Malaysian Exports

title: Patel Says FBI Headquarters to ‘Permanently Close’ With Move

title: Precious Metals Craze Prompts China Fund to Turn Away Investors

title: Russia Delays Debut Launch of New Rocket at Baiterek Project

title: Won Sees Choppy Moves After Rallying to Strongest Since November

title: Taiwan Opposition Starts Long-Shot Bid to Impeach President

title: Thailand Accuses Cambodia of New Attacks While Negotiating Peace

title: Bolsonaro Undergoes Medical Procedure to Treat Severe Hiccups

summary: Welcome to Tech In Depth, our daily newsletter about the business of tech from Bloomberg’s journalists around the world. Today, Lauren Lau gets us prepared for the coming CES tech showcase in Las Vegas.

title: Eastern Europe Makes New Push for ECB Influence
summary: Countries from the former communist bloc are mounting their strongest push yet for a seat at the top table.

title: Creators Say Spotify Pays Up to Twice as Much as YouTube for Video Podcasts
summary: The Swedish streaming giant is stepping up its courtship of YouTubers as it pushes deeper into video

title: Chicago Bears Are the NFL’s Hottest Ticket
summary: The team has surprised the league and fans by winning its division and hosting its first playoff game this decade.

title: Grok’s Image Generator Turns X Into a Deepfake Nudity Factory
summary: Welcome to Tech In Depth, our daily newsletter about the business of tech from Bloomberg’s journalists around the world. Today, Olivia Solon addresses the unintended use of AI image generation on Elon Musk’s X.

title: Take-Two Falls on ‘Grand Theft Auto VI’ Delay Misinformation
summary: “Grand Theft Auto VI’ was first announced for fall 2025 before slipping to May 2026 and then again to Nov. 19, 2026, its current planned date

title: Why Inflation May Be What Finally Brings Change to Iran
summary: Anger over a soaring cost of living has contributed to the ouster of a number of leaders in recent years.

title: 'Strong Demand for Tech Debt' as AI, M&A Booms
summary: On "Bloomberg Real Yield", Rashaan Reid, co-head of global FICC sales at the global markets division at BofA, and Patrice Altongy, head of debt capital markets at HSBC Americas, speaks with Scarlet Fu about demand for debt, the AI boom and M&A funding. Companies are hurrying to the bond market for cheap M&A funding. That’s made this quarter the biggest in four years for acquisition financing at $113 billion globally, one of the highest tallies on record, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: AI in Focus in 2026, Traders Look Past LLMs
summary: Tiffany Wade, senior portfolio manager at Columbia Threadneedle, says the fact that investors are focusing on free cashflow and return on AI investment is a sign the market is in a good place. Wade discusses her expectations for the year ahead with Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Balance Sheets Starting to Fray, Says JP Morgan’s Aliaga
summary:
JP Morgan Global Market Strategist Stephanie Aliaga discusses how investors are reacting to AI spending and private market fundraising. She joins Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.”
 (Source: Bloomberg)

title: TikTok Says It Reached a US-Majority Ownership Deal | Bloomberg Tech 12/19/2025
summary: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde discusses the plans for a US-majority-owned TikTok. Plus, former TikTok boss Kevin Mayer shares his thoughts on that deal and the broader media landscape. And Oracle shares rise as the company plays into some of the year's biggest deals. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: China Is Winning the AI Race, Says FTSG’s Webb
summary: Amy Webb, CEO of Future Today Strategy Group, says China has the edge in the AI race because it's ahead of the US in building out key infrastructure. Webb discusses why the US needs a coordinated effort to stay competitive in tech development. She joins Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Counter CEO Gregg Renfrew on Clean Beauty Industry
summary: Gregg Renfrew, founder and CEO of Counter, discusses the clean beauty industry with Romaine Bostick and Katie Greifeld on “The Close.” She says the brand evaluates ingredients across 23 different criteria to assess safety for human health, ethical sourcing, and environmental responsibility. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: DOJ Releases First Batch of Epstein Files
summary: The Justice Department released a tranche of its records on disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein, a partial disclosure that will only serve to keep interest in — and questions about — the case stoked. The material included court records and evidence from the legal case against Epstein associate Ghislaine Maxwell, who is serving a 20-year prison sentence on sex trafficking charges. Among the documents were a heavily redacted contact book a “masseuse list” that shows 254 entries, all of them blacked out. Some of the other documents had already been publicly disclosed, including more than 20,000 pages of documents released by the House Oversight Committee. Bloomberg News Senior Investigative Reporter Jason Leopold joins Bloomberg Businessweek Daily to discuss. He speaks with Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Ex-TikTok Boss Says US-Majority Ownership Plan Aids Security
summary: Former TikTok CEO Kevin Mayer says the US majority-ownership plan for the social media platform is good for users, preserving interoperability and addressing national security concerns. The co-CEO of Candle Media discusses the deal and the broader media landscape with Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Hard to Know Where to Start: Roth on Epstein Files
summary: Former Federal Prosecutor for the Southern District of New York, Jessica Roth, discusses the Department of Justice releasing the first batch of the Jeffrey Epstein files as the deadline is midnight tonight. She states "it's hard to know where to start exactly," and shares her thoughts on the DOJ holding information. Roth also talks about the amount of redactions in the files, what the DOJ's justification will be for these redactions, and if the files will meet the expectations set by US Attorney General Pam Bondi. She speaks with Joe Mathieu on the late edition of Bloomberg's "Balance of Power." (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Justice Department Releases Some Epstein Files
summary: The US Justice Department released files from investigations into notorious sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, the culmination of a push that has had repercussions for prominent business leaders and politicians, including President Donald Trump. Megan Scully has more on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Musk Wins Reinstatement of His 2018 Pay Package as CEO
summary: Elon Musk won reinstatement of his 2018 pay package as chief executive of Tesla, after the Delaware Supreme Court reversed the finding of a judge who said the billionaire had improperly influenced board members who came up with the compensation plan. Jonathan Levin has more on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Oil Prices Poised to Keep Falling With World Awash in Supply
summary: Old and new oil producers alike are ramping up output as sanctioned barrels from Russia search for buyers, putting a record 1.3 billion barrels of crude on the world’s oceans. Benchmark oil prices are heading for their biggest annual loss since the pandemic, while US gasoline at the pump is less than $3 a gallon for the first time since 2021. The drop is good news for consumers and the politicians who’ve made a point of addressing their cost-of-living concerns, including US President Donald Trump. But it’s also an economic threat to some of the largest producers, like Russia and Saudi Arabia. Oil is as cheap as it was about a decade ago, without adjusting for inflation. Bloomberg News Managing Editor for Energy and Commodities Americas Simon Casey joins Bloomberg Businessweek Daily to discuss. He speaks with Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Rep. Dina Titus on Epstein Files and US Strike in Syria
summary: Representative Dina Titus (D-NV), discusses the release of the Epstein files on the Department of Justice website and the recent US strike in Syria targeting ISIS. She tells Joe Mathieu on the late edition of Bloomberg's “Balance of Power” that covering blacked-out pages signals an attempt to hide information. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Robinhood’s Guild: AI Trade Under Pressure
summary: Robinhood’s Guild: AI Trade Under PressureStephanie Guild, Chief Investment Officer at Robinhood Markets, says earnings growth could be stronger than expected outside of tech, while select tech companies with clear utility may also outperform. She speaks with Romaine Bostick and Katie Greifeld on “The Close.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Stocks Rise as Tech and AI Names Rebound | Closing Bell
summary: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Katie Greifeld, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Teneo CEO: AI The Largest Spend Item for 2026
summary: Paul Keary, CEO and cofounder of Teneo, says CEOs are taking a longer-term view of AI as a catalyst for business transformation. He tells Romaine Bostick and Katie Greifeld on “The Close” that after a year focused on AI capital spending, the next phase will center on how enterprises transform using AI. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Stocks Climb as Options Expiry Approaches $7.1 Trillion | The Close 12/19/2025
summary: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. Today's guests are Robinhood Markets’ Stephanie Guild, CHANGE Global’s Thea Jamison, D Cowen’s Tom Fitzgerald, Navan’s Amy Butte, DWS Group’s David Bianco, Teneo’s Paul Keary, Counter’s Gregg Renfrew. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: TikTok Says It Signed Agreements for New US Joint Venture
summary:
TikTok’s long-delayed plan to separate from Chinese parent ByteDance Ltd. was put in motion Thursday when the video sharing sensation said it’s being bought by a group of buyers led by Oracle Corp.

 Bloomberg's Mandeep Singh joins to discuss with Paul Sweeney and Scarlet Fu. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: WeShop Turns Shoppers Into Shareholders
summary: John Garner, WeShop Founder and Head of Vision & Strategy, joined Bloomberg Open Interest with Matt Miller and Dani Burger, one month after its public listing on the Nasdaq. The company rewards shoppers with company shares rather than coupons or cashback. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Why This Bull Market Isn't All About Tech
summary: Ryan Detrick, Chief Market Strategist at Carson Group, offers his analysis of the stock market's recent performance and explains why he disagrees with the notion that investors are overly focused on mega-cap tech stocks. Ryan joins Carol Massar, Tim Stenovec, and Bloomberg Chartered Market Technician Bill Maloney on Bloomberg Businessweek Daily. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Africa's Tech Disruptors | Bloomberg Next Africa
summary: In this episode of Next Africa, we dive into the continent’s fast-evolving tech landscape, from booming fintech to startups tackling Africa’s digital divide. Flutterwave CEO Olugbenga Agboola says the company is on track to achieve profitability. Optasia CEO Salvador Anglada shares how the firm aims to expand across the continent and abroad after its blockbuster IPO. Plus, we explore how Fibertime is working to close South Africa’s digital divide and Axian Group’s Hassanein Hiridjee discusses how stronger telecom infrastructure can underpin Africa’s AI-driven future.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: DOJ Releases First Batch of Epstein Files | Balance of Power: Late Edition 12/19/2025
summary: "Balance of Power: Late Edition" focuses on the intersection of politics and global business. On today's show, Former Federal Prosecutor for the Southern District of New York, Jessica Roth, & Nick Akerman, Former Watergate Prosecutor, react to the Department of Justice releasing the first batch of Epstein Files. Representative Dina Titus (D-NV) discusses Secretary Hegseth announcing the US commenced strikes in Syria tied to ISIS. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Cocoa Prices are Falling. When Will Chocolate Get Cheaper?
summary: Cocoa prices have dropped from their 2024 peak — but don't expect chocolate bargains this holiday season. When will prices finally fall? Harry Black explains. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Justice Department Releases Large Tranche of Epstein Files
summary:
The US Justice Department released files from investigations into notorious sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, the culmination of a push that has had repercussions for prominent business leaders and politicians, including President Donald Trump. Myles Miller explains. 
 (Source: Bloomberg)

title: The 25-Year Shift That Made China a Global Superpower
summary: China’s entry into the WTO in 2001 accelerated its rise as a global manufacturing and technology powerhouse, fueled export growth, and helped stabilize global demand during the financial crisis. As China expanded Belt and Road investments, advanced in EVs and AI, and entered a sharper economic rivalry with the United States, its property slowdown and domestic inequality exposed new vulnerabilities. Enda Curran, Elizabeth Economy, and Afsaneh Beschloss explain China’s past 25 years and what its next phase means for the global economy. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Covid, Inflation and the GFC: The Economic Story of a Quarter-Century
summary: From Clinton-era optimism to the dot-com crash, the housing bust, a manufacturing decline that fueled MAGA, and the once-in-a-century shock of Covid, the first 25 years of the century reshaped both the economy and the public mood. Michael McKee, Jason Furman, Torsten Slok, and Stephanie Flanders explain how inflation returned, globalization shifted, and growth diverged across the US and Europe. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Wall Street Week | 25 Years of Markets
summary: This week, Wall Street Week looks back on a quarter century of change. In the first 25 years of the 21st century, capitalism endured a remarkable series of shocks - from the Y2K, to the Great Recession, to a once-in-a-century pandemic. We explore how these turning points reshaped markets, growth, and the public’s faith in the economic system. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Dalio: Why Market Crises Keep Changing the Rules for Investors
summary: The first 25 years of this century delivered one upheaval after another: the dot-com crash, the housing collapse, the Great Financial Crisis, unprecedented rounds of quantitative easing, a historic pandemic, an inflation surge, and a retail-trading revolution powered by meme stocks. Romaine Bostick charts how markets absorbed each shock, while Ray Dalio explains the deeper forces that shaped the modern investing landscape. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Y2K, iPhones, and AI: 25 Years of Tech Innovation and What Comes Next
summary: In just 25 years technology has raced from Y2K fears to smartphones to the birth of artificial intelligence. Caroline Hyde charts the transformation while Sam Palmisano and Craig Moffett explain how breakthroughs from fiber networks to quantum computing and generative AI are reshaping business and daily life. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: AI Innovation Isn't Slowing Down, Theory's Tunguz Says
summary: Tomasz Tunguz, general partner at Theory Ventures, says AI innovation isn’t showing signs of slowing down, but state-level regulation like the one recently passed in New York could hurt startups. Tunguz joins Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: AI Reshapes Rules Around IP, Content Creation
summary: Robin Feldman, professor of law at UC Law San Francisco, discusses challenges AI is raising for intellectual property rights and how that fits into broader geopolitical tensions. She joins Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Assia: Bitcoin is Digital Gold
summary: Bitcoin set to end the year lower despite a risk-on period for stocks, and demand for havens like gold. But Yoni Assia, Founder & CEO of eToro back bitcoin in his conversation with Bloomberg’s Lizzy Burden on Horizons Middle East and Africa. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Larry Ellison Backs Paramount Bid for WBD | Bloomberg Tech 12/22/2025
summary: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde discusses Larry Ellison’s personal guarantee to back Paramount Skydance’s bid for Warner Bros. Discovery. Plus, Google agrees to buy power provider Intersect Power for $4.75 billion, as the tech giant makes a push to grow its data center presence. And New York Gov. Kathy Hochul signs a bill regulating advanced artificial intelligence into law. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: BofA CEO Moynihan on Economic Outlook, AI and Fed Rate Cuts
summary: Bank of America Chair and CEO Brian Moynihan says the US consumer is in "pretty good shape" going into 2026. Speaking with David Westin on Bloomberg Television, Moynihan also says the Federal Reserve will have room to cut rates next year. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: BofA CEO Moynihan Sees AI Driving Strong Economy in 2026
summary: Bank of America Chair and CEO Brian Moynihan comments on the economic outlook for 2026 and how much artificial intelligence will play a role during an interview with David Westin on Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Dan Ives on Nvidia, Clean Energy, Tesla
summary: Wedbush Securities Global Head of Tech Research Dan Ives discusses Nvidia as shipments to China are expected to start soon, according to Reuters. Ives speaks with Joe Mathieu on “Balance of Power.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Data Center Demand a Long-Term Real Estate Driver: Bell
summary: Elizabeth Bell, Co-Head of Real Estate at Hamilton Lane, says demand for data centers has surged more than 200% since 2010, driven largely by cloud computing and digital transformation. She tells Romaine Bostick and Katie Greifeld on “The Close” that computing needs are accelerating while data center supply is struggling to keep up. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: US Pursuit of Third Oil Tanker Intensifies Venezuela Blockade | Daybreak Europe 12/22/2025
summary:
On today's show, gold rose to an all-time high on expectations for more Fed rate cuts. Silver and copper also climbed to records. Asian equities and US futures advanced on hopes for a year-end rally.

Oil gaining as Donald Trump intensified a blockade on Venezuela, boarding one tanker and pursuing another within weeks of first capturing a vessel. Venezuela condemned the boarding on Saturday. 

The Trump administration has defended the decision to pull several pictures from the latest release of documents related to Jeffrey Epstein. An image of a desk drawer with a number of photos, including one showing President Trump, was among those removed and then later restored. 
                                                                                            
Today's guests: Kaiko CEO Ambre Soubiran, Bruegel Non-resident Fellow Elina Ribakova & Co-Founder & General Partner Giant Ventures, Tommy Stadlen (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Gold Climbs to Record High Amid Geopolitical Tensions
summary: Gold rose to an all-time high as escalating geopolitical tensions and bets on further US rate cuts added momentum to the best annual performance in more than four decades. Bloomberg’s Martin Ritchie breaks down the situation.

title: Horizons Middle East & Africa 12/22/2026
summary: Horizons Middle East & Africa is your daily spotlight on one of the world's fastest-growing regions. Live from Dubai, we bring you the latest global markets and analysis, plus news-making interviews, with a special focus on MEA. All that and more, as you head to the office in the Gulf, pause for lunch in Hong Kong, or start your day in London or Johannesburg.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: HSBC's Sels on AI, Capex Cycle
summary: Willem Sels from HSBC discusses artificial intelligence and the capex cycle. "Investment is going to the delta, so the growth rate of investment is going to slow," he tells Bloomberg Television. "We think that's going to slow to 45% from a higher base," Sels adds. "Still very substantial and still going to drive a lot of economic growth." (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Supercharged Gold, Silver Keep Global Risk Rally On | Insight with Haslinda Amin 12/22/2025
summary: Insight with Haslinda Amin, a daily news program featuring in-depth, high-profile interviews and analysis to give viewers the complete picture on the stories that matter. The show features prominent leaders spanning the worlds of business, finance, politics and culture. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Jacobio Strikes New Cancer Drug Deal with AstraZeneca
summary: Hong Kong-listed Chinese biotech firm Jacobio Pharma says it hopes to commercialize a new drug that it's developing with AstraZeneca. Speaking on Bloomberg's "The China Show," the company's Co-CEO, Chief Medical Officer and Global Head of R&D Andrea Wang-Gillam discusses the significance of the Pan-KRAS inhibitor and her company's business outlook. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Li Ka-shing Remakes His Empire
summary: Li Ka-shing and his family set in motion a series of deals this year that stand to completely transform his business empire. Bloomberg's Shirley Zhao shares the context on The China Show. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Nasdaq's Thomas: Expect Strong End of '26 for IPOs
summary: Jeff Thomas, Nasdaq Capital Access Platforms chief revenue officer and global head of listings, says activity should pick up strongly in the first quarter and accelerate further in the back half of the year. He tells Romaine Bostick and Katie Greifeld on “The Close” that he expects a strong year ahead. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Netanyahu Expected in the US to Meet Trump
summary: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is expected to travel to the US later this month to meet with President Trump. t comes as talks on the phase 2 of the Gaza peace process are slowly advancing. Bloomberg's Dan Williams reports.   (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Rising Bond Yields Will Be Key for 2026: 3-Minute MLIV
summary: Anna Edwards, Guy Johnson and Adam Linton break down today's key themes for analysts and investors on "Bloomberg: The Opening Trade."  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: SGMC's Gomes on Tech Valuations
summary: SGCM Capital CIO Ed Gomes speaks on Bloomberg's Insight about the challenges facing investors in accurately appraising valuations of tech stocks. He speaks as Republican lawmakers ask the Pentagon to a list a group of Chinese firms including domestic tech innovators as affiliated with China's military. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Shein’s French Faux Pas Won’t Keep It Out of the Market
summary: Shein is proving that it’s here to stay in Paris, even after a political backlash and controversy over sales of sex dolls and weapons. Jenny Che explains how French efforts to resist the fast-fashion retailer are falling flat. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Tech, BOJ Drive Rally in Asia | The Asia Trade 12/22/25
summary: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. Bloomberg TV is live from Australia with Annabelle Droulers and Paul Allen, getting insight and analysis from newsmakers and industry leaders on the biggest stories shaping global markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Moore Threads Jumps After Unveiling New AI Chips | The China Show 12/22/2025
summary: “Bloomberg: The China Show” is your definitive source for news and analysis on the world's second-biggest economy. From politics and policy to tech and trends, David Ingles and Annabelle Droulers give global investors unique insight, delivering in-depth discussions with the newsmakers who matter. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Stocks Advance as Gold and Silver Hit Record Highs | The Close 12/22/2025
summary: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. Today's guests are Morgan Stanley’s Kathy Entwistle, Gerber Kawasaki Wealth and Investment Management’s Ross Gerber, HSBC’s Eric Fisch, Charles Schwab’s Liz Ann Sonders, Nasdaq’s Jeff Thomas, NEPC’s Sarah Samuels, Hamilton Lane’s Elizabeth Bell. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: TikTok Deal Leaves National Security Risk, Garnaut’s Tobin Says
summary: Liza Tobin, managing director at Garnaut Global, says the Trump administration has been lowering the bar on national security concerns related to TikTok as it works to find a deal to keep the app in the US. She joins Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Trump Announces Plan to Build New Navy Battleships
summary: President Donald Trump says he has approved a plan for the US Navy to begin the construction of two new battleships. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: US Pursuit of Oil Tanker Intensifies Venezuela Blockade
summary: The US’s pursuit of a third oil tanker off the coast of Venezuela has intensified a blockade that President Donald Trump’s administration hopes will cut off a vital economic lifeline for the country and isolate the government of President Nicolás Maduro. Bloomberg’s Stephen Stapczynski breaks down the situation and the possible impact on oil markets.

title: US, Ukraine Had ‘Productive’ Talks, Witkoff Says
summary: US administration officials held “productive and constructive” meetings with Ukrainian and European counterparts in Florida, special envoy Steve Witkoff said. The talks, which are part of ongoing efforts to end the war in Ukraine, included President Donald Trump’s son-in-law Jared Kushner, top Ukrainian negotiator Rustem Umerov and other European security advisers. Bloomberg’s Jill Disis reports.

title: Venezuela Actions Not Declaration of War: Wesley Clark
summary: Former NATO Supreme Allied Commander for Europe, US Southern Command Former Commander in Chief Gen. Wesley Clark speaks on "Balance of Power" as the US pursues a 3rd tanker off the coast of Venezuela. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Warner Bros. Has Done 'Masterful' Job, Ross Gerber Says
summary: "This is quite a battle," Ross Gerber, co-founder and CEO of Gerber Kawasaki Wealth and Investment Management, says about the latest in the Paramount and Netflix bids for Warner Bros. He speaks on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

title: WBD Bids Could Go Higher, Says Former CNN President Klein
summary: Bids for Warner Bros. Discovery could go higher, and the company’s cable networks may be worth more if sold separately from the studio assets, says Jon Klein, co-founder of Hang Media and former president of CNN. He joins Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: What Is the AI Trade in 2026?
summary: Overexuberance and complacency dog the market and the AI trade going into next year, says Ted Mortonson, managing director of Baird. He discusses the headwinds he sees around the corner with Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Decorated Army Veteran Builds Second Career in the Bourbon Business
summary: As the alcohol industry contends with the impact of tariffs, Lofted Spirits continues to excel thanks to two of the fastest-growing brands on the American whiskey market, Bardstown Bourbon and Green River. The company also has a unique brand of leadership in the C-Suite with CEO Mark Erwin at the helm. The retired US Army Colonel explains how his firm is navigating a challenged market and solidifying itself among the most reliable custom contract distilleries in the nation. Col. Erwin speaks with Carol Massar, Tim Stenovec and Bloomberg Wall Street Week host David Westin on Bloomberg Businessweek Daily. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Venezuela Blockade Intensifies; Health Care Fight Lingers | Balance of Power 12/22/2025
summary: "Balance of Power" focuses on the intersection of politics and global business. On today's show, Former NATO Supreme Allied Commander for Europe, US Southern Command Former Commander in Chief Gen. Wesley Clark, Wedbush Securities Global Head of Tech Research Dan Ives, Harvard Kennedy School Belfer Center Director of Arctic Initiatives Jennifer Spence, Stonecourt Capital Partner Rick Davis, Harvard Kennedy School Ash Center Democracy Visiting Fellow Jeanne Sheehan Zaino. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Big Nvidia Buyer Faces Smuggling Probe
summary: The US government is investigating whether Nvidia's biggest buyer in Southeast Asia has smuggled chips into China. Bloomberg’s Ian King discusses the details with Caroline Hyde on "Bloomberg Tech." (Source: Bloomberg)

title: GDP Surprise Pushes Stocks Higher  | Bloomberg Businessweek Daily 12/23/2025
summary: On today's episode of Bloomberg Businessweek Daily, Caroline Hyde and Romaine Bostic discuss today's surprise GDP release pushing stocks higher during a holiday-shortened trading week. Bloomberg's Emily Graffeo joins the show to break it down. Also on today's show, Compass Chief Economist Mike Simonsen examines the real estate market as it sees a long-term post-pandemic shift. Plus, Ashley Global Retail CEO Chad Spencer discusses the furniture giant's new AI e-commerce assistant. Finally, FG Nexus Digital Assets CEO Maja Vujinovic on the outlook for cryptocurrencies in 2026, and Merk Investments CIO Axel Merk discusses gold and silver rising to new records on rate cut bets and global risks. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: ETHZilla Makes Second Ether Sale, 2026 Crypto Regulation Expectations | Bloomberg Crypto 12/23/2025
summary: "Bloomberg Crypto" covers the people, transactions, and technology shaping the world of decentralized finance. Today's guests: Strive CEO Matt Cole and Zerohash CEO Edward Woodford. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Nvidia Buyer Megaspeed Faces Smuggling Probe | Bloomberg Tech 12/23/2025
summary: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde discusses ServiceNow’s plan to buy cybersecurity startup Armis for $7.75 billion, its largest acquisition to date. Plus, Nvidia's biggest buyer in Southeast Asia, Megaspeed, faces a chip-smuggling probe. And it was supposed to be crypto’s big year, but some of the sector's billionaires have been hit hard by recent price drops. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Trump Warns Maduro Not to Play ‘Tough’ But Won’t Threaten Ouster | Daybreak Europe 12/23/2025
summary:
Bloomberg Daybreak Europe is your essential morning viewing to stay ahead. Live from London, we set the agenda for your day, catching you up with overnight markets news from the US and Asia. And we'll tell you what matters for investors in Europe, giving you insight before trading begins.

On today's show, President Donald Trump warned President Nicolas Maduro not to challenge the US and vowed to keep oil seized from a supertanker but declined to say if he’s seeking to oust the Venezuelan leader. 

Novo’s ADRs surged after the company won FDA approval to sell a pill version of its Wegovy blockbuster obesity drug, a crucial step in its effort to protect its market share from Eli Lilly.

Larry Ellison gives a $40 billion-plus guarantee to backstop Paramount’s bid for Warner Bros.
                                                                                                                  
Today's guest: DTEK CEO Maxim Timchenko. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: ECB Hike Bets Likely Peaked for Now: 3-Minute MLIV
summary: Anna Edwards, Lizzy Burden and Adam Linton break down today's key themes for analysts and investors on "Bloomberg: The Opening Trade."  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Expect 'Massive Adoption' of Account-to-Account Movements: zerohash CEO
summary: Edward Woodford, CEO of crypto-infrastructure startup zerohash, joins "Bloomberg Crypto" to discuss the growth of stablecoins in the US, banks' usage of the technology and the overall growing institutional adoption of digital assets. He speaks with Bloomberg's Scarlet Fu and Katie Greifeld. The company builds stablecoin and blockchain infrastructure that allows for payments and crypto trading. The firm, founded in 2017, has settled more than $65 billion of transaction volume, according to its website.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Fashionphile CEO on Differentiating in Luxury Resale
summary: Ben Hemminger, CEO and co founder of Fashionphile, says the company’s specialty allows it to price items accurately and buy directly from sellers, taking on the resale risk itself. He speaks with Romaine Bostick and Katie Greifeld on “The Close.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Hard to Define Competition in Streaming: Yale’s Scott Morton
summary: Defining what counts as competition in streaming is difficult, says Fiona Scott Morton, Professor of Economics at the Yale University School of Management and an Adjunct Professor at Yale Law School. Scott Morton discusses what this could mean for Netflix’s bid to buy Warner Bros. Discovery. She joins Caroline Hyde on "Bloomberg Tech." (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Heritage Foundation Shifts Toward Trump Mode: Rick Davis
summary: Rick Davis, Stonecourt Capital partner and Republican strategist, says the Heritage Foundation has shifted sharply toward a Trump-centric approach, moving away from its traditional Republican roots and, in his view, damaging its brand. Speaking on "Balance of Power" Democratic strategist Jeanne Sheehan Zaino of Harvard Kennedy School’s Ash Center added that there could be a potential challenge to JD Vance emerging within the party. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Horizons Middle East & Africa 12/23/2026
summary: Horizons Middle East & Africa is your daily spotlight on one of the world's fastest-growing regions. Live from Dubai, we bring you the latest global markets and analysis, plus news-making interviews, with a special focus on MEA. All that and more, as you head to the office in the Gulf, pause for lunch in Hong Kong, or start your day in London or Johannesburg.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Huawei's Maybach Rival is a Top-Seller in China
summary: Huawei Technologies Co.'s Maextro S800 sedan is outselling Porsche AG's Panamera, Mercedes-Benz Group AG's S-Class and all other vehicles with sticker prices of at least $100,000 in China. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Equity Rally Endures; New Zealand-India FTA | Insight with Haslinda Amin 12/23/2025
summary: Insight with Haslinda Amin, a daily news program featuring in-depth, high-profile interviews and analysis to give viewers the complete picture on the stories that matter. The show features prominent leaders spanning the worlds of business, finance, politics and culture. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Invesco Sees Fed Rate Cuts Boosting Equities in 2026
summary: Invesco strategist Ben Gutteridge discusses the outlook for the US economy, Fed policy and markets in the run up to 2026 and for the year ahead. “The more benign inflationary outlook is giving cover for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates,” Gutteridge says on Bloomberg Television. “That has something of a Goldilocks flavor to it, and that leaves us feeling positive about equities in 2026.”

title: It Was Supposed to be Crypto's Big Year
summary: 2025 was supposed to be a big year for crypto with a friendly administration in the White House and more financial firms embracing digital assets, but it didn’t work out for all investors. Stillmark Managing Partner Alyse Killeen discusses what went well for the industry and what it will push for in 2026. She joins Caroline Hyde on "Bloomberg Tech." (Source: Bloomberg)

title: ITI CEO on the Tech Industry's Roadmap for 2026
summary: Jason Oxman, president and CEO of the Information Technology Industry Association, discusses the data center buildout, AI regulation and tech export restrictions. He joins Caroline Hyde on "Bloomberg Tech." (Source: Bloomberg)

title: JPMorgan Is Exploring Crypto Trading for Institutional Clients
summary: JPMorgan is considering offering cryptocurrency trading to its institutional clients, as large banks around the world deepen their involvement in the asset class. The Wall Street giant is assessing what products and services its markets division could offer to expand its footprint in cryptocurrencies, according to a person familiar with the plans. This could include spot and derivatives trading, said the person who asked not to be identified as the plans are not public. Bloomberg's Lauren Tara LaCapra reports on "Bloomberg Crypto". (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Legacki, Martinez on Kennedy Center Renaming, Approval Ratings
summary: President Donald Trump was sued for adding his name last week to that of Washington’s premier art venue — The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts — without approval from Congress. Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo Former Senior Advisor, Democratic Strategist Caitlin Legacki and Principles First Executive Director, Republican Strategist Brittany Martinezdiscuss the Kennedy Center, political approval ratings, and the President’s Christmas portrait.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Novo Gets Approval to Sell Wegovy Obesity Pill in the US
summary: Novo Nordisk A/S won approval to sell a pill version of its obesity shot Wegovy in the US. Novo will start selling the pill, the first of the blockbuster GLP-1 class, in the US in early January. It is approved to help people lose weight or maintain previous weight loss over the long term. Bloomberg’s Amber Tong reports.

title: Why Writing Off China Is a Huge Mistake
summary: Remember China’s DeepSeek moment? China had moments like that in biotech and defense in 2025, too, Bloomberg Opinion columnist Shuli Ren explains. That’s why underestimating the country is a huge mistake. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Opportunities for Firms in India: NZ's Trade Minister
summary: New Zealand companies will get more opportunities to invest in India under the terms of the two nations’ new free-trade accord, Trade Minister Todd McClay tells Bloomberg. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Reichste Dynastien
summary: Im laufenden Jahr konnten die 25 reichsten Familien der Welt ihr gemeinsames Vermögen auf rund 2,9 Billionen Dollar steigern. Die Gründe für ihren Reichtum variieren. Das sind die Top fünf der wohlhabendsten Dynastien. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Rep. Auchincloss on Venezuela: This Is All About Oil
summary: Rep. Jake Auchincloss (D-MA) speaks with Joe Mathieu on “Balance of Power” about the latest news from the Wall Street Journal that the US will be moving more troops into the Caribbean. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Robert McWhirter on Epstein File Redactions
summary: Law Office of Robert McWhirter Founder and Constitutional Lawyer Robert McWhirter discusses the latest regarding the Jeffrey Epstein files release and redactions. He speaks with Joe Mathieu on “Balance of Power.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Seeing K-Shaped Economy: Groundwork Collaborative's Jacquez
summary: Groundwork Collaborative Chief of Policy and Advocacy Alex Jacquez discusses the US economy and the Fed. He speak with Joe Mathieu on “Balance of Power.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Stocks May Get A Boost If Supreme Court Strikes Tariffs
summary: Wall Street forecasts that US stocks are poised for another year of solid gains next year but several wildcards could disrupt the bullish narrative. Tatiana Darie has more. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Strive CEO Discusses the Future of DATs as Stocks Slide
summary: Digital asset treasuries, or DATs, turned into one of the hottest trends in the public markets in 2025, as share prices skyrocketed and everyone from Peter Thiel to the Trump family piled in. What began though as one of the best trades in the stock market has, in a matter of months, turned into one of the worst. Strive CEO Matt Cole joins "Bloomberg Crypto" to discuss the recent decline in digital asset treasury (DAT) stocks, the rapid growth of DATs in 2025 and the controversy surrounding MSCI. Cole speaks to Bloomberg's Scarlet Fu and Katie Greifeld.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Syrian Army, SDF Clash Before Integration Deadline
summary: Fresh clashes between the Syrian army and the US-backed group SDF have erupted in northern Syria. The clashes coincide with a visit of Turkish ministers to Syria. Bloomberg's Patrick Sykes reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

summary: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. Bloomberg TV is live from Australia and Singapore with Annabelle Droulers and Avril Hong, getting insight and analysis from newsmakers and industry leaders on the biggest stories shaping global markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

summary: “Bloomberg: The China Show” is your definitive source for news and analysis on the world's second-biggest economy. From politics and policy to tech and trends, David Ingles and Annabelle Droulers give global investors unique insight, delivering in-depth discussions with the newsmakers who matter. (Source: Bloomberg)

summary: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: There Are Too Many DATs Right Now: Strive CEO
summary: Strive CEO Matt Cole joins "Bloomberg Crypto" to discuss the recent decline in digital asset treasury (DAT) stocks, the rapid growth of DATs in 2025 and the controversy surrounding MSCI. Cole speaks to Bloomberg's Scarlet Fu and Katie Greifeld. MSCI is deciding whether companies whose digital asset holdings represent 50% or more of their total assets should be excluded or not from the MSCI Global Investable Market Indexes because they’re more like investment funds than operational companies.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Thiel-Backed Crypto Hoarder ETHZilla Sells Tokens to Pay Debt
summary: ETHZilla, a cryptocurrency accumulator backed by billionaire Peter Thiel, appears to be shifting focus as investors abandon what was briefly one of the stock market’s hottest trades. Just four months after the former 180 Life Sciences Corp. rebranded itself as a digital asset treasury company centered on buying Ether - the second largest cryptocurrency after Bitcoin - it sold $74.5 million worth of the tokens to pay down debt, according to a filing Friday with the SEC. Bloomberg's David Pan reports on "Bloomberg Crypto". (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Trump Is Rerouting Trillions in Capital During His Second Term
summary: In the first year of his second administration, Donald Trump and his advisers set the stage for the rerouting of trillions of dollars in capital in the US economy. Bloomberg's Allison McNeely explains. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Trump Warns Venezuela’s Maduro, Vows to Keep Tankers
summary: President Donald Trump, speaking at a press conference at his Mar-a-Lago estate on Monday evening, warned Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro not to challenge the US and vowed to keep oil seized from a supertanker. The US stepped up its blockade of tankers going to and from Venezuela over the weekend. Bloomberg’s Brian Fowler reports.

title: Why ServiceNow Is Buying Cyber Startup Armis for $7.75 Billion
summary: ServiceNow President and COO Amit Zavery explains why the company agreed to buy the cybersecurity startup Armis in a deal valued at $7.75 billion. He speaks on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Ziemba: Gold Looks the Way to Play Weaker Dollar
summary: Gold rose to a record high — the 50th day it’s done so this year — on escalating geopolitical tensions and prospects for more US rate cuts. Silver also set an all-time peak. Meanwhile oil edged slightly lower after a four-day run of gains as the US continued its blockade of shipments of crude from Venezuela. Rachel Ziemba, Founder of Ziemba Insights spoke to Bloomberg’s Lizzy Burden on Horizons Middle East and Africa on the impact of geopolitical tensions on commodities. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: 'Santa Claus Rally' Started Early, Dawson Says
summary: Cameron Dawson of Newedge Wealth says the "Santa Claus Rally" seemed to start earlier this year, but they don't read much into it because it's just end of the year position chasing. She is on "Bloomberg Surveillance." (Source: Bloomberg)

title: AI Demand Top of Mind for PC, Hardware Giants in 2026
summary: Woo Jin Ho, Bloomberg Intelligence Senior Technology Analyst, joins Paul Sweeney and Kristine Aquino on Bloomberg Intelligence to discuss the 2026 outlook for the PC and computer hardware market, including Micron, Dell, HP, and more. AI is top of mind for these companies as server demand continues to accelerate. Dell in particular is expected to see a broadening customer base that will support a high-single-digit compound annual growth rate through fiscal 2030. Robust AI order activity and stable traditional server and storage trends will help sustain momentum. Elsewhere, Micron's 2026 DRAM-supply outlook offers little relief for HP and Dell's PC sales and margin. Micron expects DRAM-supply tightness at least through 2026 and into 2027, which forces personal-computer manufacturers to make tradeoffs between PC units and sales, especially at the higher end. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: America is 'Hopelessly Divided' Headed Into 2026, Says Frank Luntz
summary: Frank Luntz, pollster and CEO of FIL Inc., says America is 'hopelessly divided' by political affiliation as he reflects on 2025 and what he expects from an equally divided Congress of 2026. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Baby Bonds vs. Trump Accounts
summary: A new savings vehicle, dubbed “Trump accounts,” is designed to help the rising generation of American children build wealth into adulthood. Under the multitrillion-dollar tax and spending bill signed by President Donald Trump in July, the federal government will contribute $1,000 to accounts set up for every American baby born in the next few years. Darrick Hamilton, Henry Cohen Professor of Economics and Urban Policy at the New School, is behind a comparable concept known as "baby bonds," which he sees as a means to granting more social mobility and agency to young people regardless of family income levels. Professor Hamilton compares and contrasts his idea with the Trump administration's mechanism with Alexis Christoforous and Isabelle Lee on Bloomberg Businessweek Daily. (Source: Bloomberg)

summary: "Balance of Power" focuses on the intersection of politics and global business. On today's show,Rep. Jake Auchincloss (D-MA), Groundwork Collaborative Chief of Policy and Advocacy Alex Jacquez, Law Office of Robert McWhirter Founder and Constitutional Lawyer Robert McWhirter, Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo Former Senior Advisor, Democratic Strategist Caitlin Legacki and Principles First Executive Director, Republican Strategist Brittany Martinez. summary: Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz and Annmarie Hordern speak daily with leaders and decision makers from Wall Street to Washington and beyond. No other program better positions investors and executives for the trading day. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Intel Shares Fall on Reports Nvidia to Halt Chipmaking Tests | Bloomberg Tech 12/24/2025
summary: Bloomberg’s Katie Greifeld examines Intel as shares fall after reports emerge that Nvidia may be hitting pause on testing Intel’s chip production process. Plus, the Trump administration gets the go-ahead to move forward with a $100,000 fee on new H-1B visa applications. And Tesla faces renewed scrutiny over car doors, with the company confronting a new probe by the NHTSA. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: BOE to Disappoint Dovish Bets in 2026:  3-Minute MLIV
summary: Anna Edwards, Lizzy Burden and Adam Linton break down today's key themes for analysts and investors on "Bloomberg: The Opening Trade."  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: BP to Sell Majority Stake of Castrol to Stonepeak
summary: BP Plc agreed to sell a majority stake in its Castrol lubricants division to Stonepeak Partners to raise about $6 billion. The UK oil giant will divest a 65% stake, retaining the remaining interest via a joint venture. Bloomberg’s Mitchell Ferman reports.

title: Brinc Drones CEO on Business Outlook
summary: Blake Resnick, Founder and CEO of Brinc Drones, discusses his outlook for business growth and opportunities as the US Federal Communications Commission moves to block foreign-made drones and critical components for unmanned aircraft systems. He speaks with Annabelle Droulers and Avril Hong on "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade". (Source: Bloomberg)

title: H-1B Visa Fee Upheld & US Sanctions Former EU Official | Daybreak Europe 12/24/2025
summary:
Bloomberg Daybreak Europe is your essential morning viewing to stay ahead. Live from London, we set the agenda for your day, catching you up with overnight markets news from the US and Asia. And we'll tell you what matters for investors in Europe, giving you insight before trading begins.

On today's show, a federal judge has ruled that the Trump administration can go ahead with imposing a $100,000 fee on new H-1B visa applications. The decision is a setback for US tech companies that rely on hiring skilled foreign workers.

The Trump administration has imposed visa sanctions on former EU Commissioner Thierry Breton and four other people for trying to make American tech companies police political speech.
                                                                                                                  
Today's guests: Ukrainian Prism Director of Security Programmes Hanna Shelest & Antler Partner Christoph Klink. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Consumer Debt is Possible Headwind for Retail, Says EY-Parthenon's Auchincloss
summary:
US consumer sentiment rose in December by less than expected, remaining depressed amid lingering affordability concerns.
The University of Michigan’s final December sentiment index climbed 1.9 points to 52.9, according to a report released Friday. The median estimate in a Bloomberg survey of economists called for a reading of 53.5.
“Despite some signs of improvement to close out the year, sentiment remains nearly 30% below December 2024, as pocketbook issues continue to dominate consumer views of the economy,” Joanne Hsu, director of the survey, said in a statement.
The current conditions gauge slid to a record-low of 50.4, while a gauge of expectations climbed to a four-month high. Consumers’ perception of current buying conditions for big-ticket items deteriorated to the lowest on record. Will Auchincloss, Americas Retail Sector Leader at EY-Parthenon, breaks down the state of the consumer. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Horizons Middle East & Africa 12/24/2025
summary: Horizons Middle East & Africa is your daily spotlight on one of the world's fastest-growing regions. Live from Dubai, we bring you the latest global markets and analysis, plus news-making interviews, with a special focus on MEA. All that and more, as you head to the office in the Gulf, pause for lunch in Hong Kong, or start your day in London or Johannesburg.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Insight with Haslinda Amin 12/24/2025
summary: Insight with Haslinda Amin, a daily news program featuring in-depth, high-profile interviews and analysis to give viewers the complete picture on the stories that matter. The show features prominent leaders spanning the worlds of business, finance, politics and culture. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Intel Declines; Dynavax Rallies; Nike Ticks Higher
summary:
- Shares of Intel (INTC) fell in the early session after Reuters reported that Nvidia halted a test that uses the chip manufacturer’s 18A technology to produce its chips. 
- Shares of Dynavax Technologies (DVAX) soared in premarket trading after Sanofi agreed to buy Dynavax for about $2.2 billion, as it seeks to expand a vaccines business currently anchored by its flu shot franchise. The French drugmaker will pay $15.50 a share in cash for Dynavax, 39% above the Emeryville, California-based firm’s closing price Tuesday. 
- Shares of Nike (NKE) moved higher ahead of the US market open after a filing shows that Apple CEO Tim Cook purchased $2.95 million worth of shares on December 22nd.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Intel Under Pressure on Report Nvidia Halts Production Test
summary: Intel shares fell Wednesday after a report said that Nvidia Corp. halted a test to use Intel’s production process to make advanced chips. Nvidia recently tested the so-called 18A process but stopped moving forward, Reuters reported, citing two unidentified people familiar with the matter. Spokespeople for Nvidia and Intel didn’t immediately respond to requests for comment. An Intel spokesperson told Reuters that the company’s 18A manufacturing technologies are “progressing well.” Bloomberg News Equities Reporter Ryan Vlastelica joins Bloomberg Intelligence to discuss. He speaks with Paul Sweeney and Kristine Aquino. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Jet Crash in Turkey Kills Libyan Military Chief of Staff
summary: A private jet carrying Libya’s military chief of staff, Mohammed Ali Ahmed al-Haddad, crashed in central Turkey, killing him and seven others, Libya’s internationally recognized government said. Bloomberg’s Onur Ant reports.

title: Judge Upholds Trump's $100,000 H-1B Visa Fee
summary: A federal judge said the Trump administration can move ahead with a $100,000 fee on new H-1B visa applications, providing a setback for US technology companies. Bloomberg's Kasia Klimasinska reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: M&A to Be 2026 Theme: State Street Investment Management
summary: "I do think M&A is back," State Street Investment Management's Altaf Kassam tells Bloomberg Television. "Consolidation, the rewiring of the global trade order, I think that all comes together into spurring M&A to improve efficiency," he adds. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Nvidia Stops Test Using Intel's Chip Production Process
summary: Intel Corp. shares fell after a report said Nvidia stopped a test using Intel's production process to make advanced chips. The report from from Reuters. Norah Mulinda reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Nvidia Stops Testing Intel Chipmaking Technology | Open Interest 12/24/2025
summary: Get a jump start on the US trading day with Vonnie Quinn and Emily Graffeo on "Bloomberg Open Interest." Nvidia stops a test that uses Intel technology to make advanced chips as the AI race continues to heat up as Washington lands a blow to Silicon Valley. A federal judge rules the Trump administration can move ahead with a $100,000 fee on new H-1B visa applications, a ruling viewed as a setback for US tech. Plus The RealReal's Rati Levesque joined Bloomberg Open Interest to give a read on the secondary luxury market ahead of the holiday season. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Elon’s Erratic 2025
summary: From Trump to Tesla, Elon Musk has had rocky 2025, explains Bloomberg Opinion columnist Liam Denning. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Recess CEO: Building a Leading Relaxation Beverage Brand

He tells Katie Greifeld and Norah Mulinda on The Close that Recess is positioning its drinks as an evening relaxation option instead of a glass of wine. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Rich World's Rate-Cut Momentum Fading Away
summary: This year has seen a series of rate cuts across major central banks around the world. But with many policy-makers signaling they're near or at the end of that cycle, what does 2026 have in store for central bank watchers? Bloomberg's MLIV Currency and Rates Strategist Ven Ram explains. (Source: Bloomberg)

summary: Dana Telsey, Telsey Advisory Group CEO and chief research officer, says the consumer continues to show resilience. She tells Norah Mulinda and Katie Greifeld on “The Close” that tariffs and price increases remain ahead and could further pressure the retail landscape. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: US Aggression Near Venezuela is 'Oil Based,' Says Denver Riggleman
summary: Former Representative Denver Riggleman said that recent moves by the US military to sure up capabilities around Latin America are driven by oil and not drug trafficking, as the Trump administration ramps up aggression in the region. Riggleman also gives his perspective on the divisions within the Republican party as it contends differing views on the Epstein files and international conflict. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: US Weighs Conference to Rebuild Gaza in Fresh Ceasefire
summary:
The US and its allies are renewing their push to hold a conference on Gaza reconstruction, people familiar with the matter said, as the Trump administration looks to inject fresh momentum into a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas after a string of setbacks.
Washington has been discussed as a potential venue for the conference that could happen as early as next month, according to the people, who asked not to be identified discussing private conversations. Egypt is among several other locations also being considered, one of the people said.
That person said the event would probably take place only after officials fill out the Board of Peace that will oversee a transitional government and whose creation was spelled out in the ceasefire that ended the fighting between Israel and Hamas and was signed in October. Bloomberg's Dan Williams reports from Jerusalem. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: WBD Deal May Reshape American Media: Alpha's Wolfe Pereira
summary: Steven Wolfe Pereira, CEO and founder of Alpha, says Netflix will have to “up the ante” after Paramount’s latest offer for Warner Bros. Discovery. He joins Katie Greifeld on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: 2026 Outlook For Dealmaking
summary: Bloomberg's Nina Trentmann discusses the outlook for dealmaking in 2026, the impact of geopolitics, how less deals have been challenged by FTC and DOJ, and the prospect of lowering financing costs with Vonnie Quinn and Isabelle Lee on 'Bloomberg Markets.' (Source: Bloomberg)

Ranking Member Jane Harman, Macy’s Tony Spring, Stonecourt Capital and Bloomberg Contributor Rick Davis, FTC and Democratic Strategist Doug Farrar, Fmr. US Ambassador to Ukraine and Atlantic Council Eurasia Center SNR. Director John Herbst, Bank of America’s Brian Moynihan, and Kiss Band's Gene Simmons. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Ellison, Paramount Put Pressure on WBD for a Deal
summary: Warner Bros. Discovery shares slid early Friday in premarket trading after a report from the New York Post said that Paramount Skydance could walk away from its $30-per-share cash bid and instead litigate against the company’s board for how it handled the process. But with Larry Ellison personally backing the Paramount bid, the pressure is still on. Bloomberg's Chris Palmeri reports.  (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Fmr. Rep. Harman on Russia and Ukraine, Middle East, Nigeria
summary: Jane Harman, Fmr. US Representative (D-CA) and House Intelligence Committee Fmr. Ranking Member, says she is pessimist because I don’t see that Putin will be satisfied with this deal. She speaks with Joe Mathieu on “Balance of Power.” (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Gold, Silver Smash Records as End-Of-Year Rally Continues
summary: Gold, silver, and platinum extended a historic end-of-year rally for precious metals, jumping to all-time highs, with spot gold peaking above $4,530 an ounce. Tatiana Darie has more on Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Holiday Spending Was Practical, Predictable Says Julia Wilson
summary: Julia Wilson, principal of consumer and retail strategy at KPMG, said that practical items like sweaters and gift cards were at the top of consumers' shopping lists this holiday season. Wilson also said that for tricky post-holiday tasks like returning or exchanging gifts, consumers are turning to chatbots for help. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Musk on Tesla, ‘DOGE’ and Political Spending
summary: As the year draws to a close, we bring you one of Mishal Husain’s biggest conversations of the year, in full. In May, Elon Musk joined Bloomberg's Qatar Economic Forum in a rare media appearance. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Zelenskiy to Meet Trump on Sunday in Florida to Discuss Peace Plan
summary:
John Herbst, former U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine and senior director at the Atlantic Council’s Eurasia Center, says negotiations between the U.S. and Ukraine have made progress, but notes that Vladimir Putin has rejected every proposal so far. Ukraine's Zelenskiy says he expects to meet President Trump on Sunday in Florida to talk about a plan.
Speaking with Joe Mathieu on "Balance of Power," Herbst adds that China is closely watching the war and does not want Putin to lose. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Nvidia Up on AI Licensing Deal, Biohaven Down on Study Results, Coforge Up
summary:
- Shares of Nvidia (NVDA) edge higher in the premarket session as the company agreed to a licensing deal with artificial intelligence startup Groq.

- Shares of Indian technology services provider Coforge Ltd. (COFORGE IN) declined ahead of the US market open after the company agreed to buy Encora at an enterprise value of $2.35 billion in an all-stock deal.

- Shares of Biohaven (BHVN) fell as much 14 percent in US premarket trading after a mid-stage study of the company’s experimental drug BHV-7000 for the treatment of major depressive disorder missed the primary endpoint. Trends favoring BHV-7000 were observed in some clinically relevant subgroups, including participants with more severe depression at screening and baseline, on primary and secondary outcome measures. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Reasonable to be Optimistic About Markets in 2026, Says Rick Gardner
summary: Rick Gardner, CIO of RGA Investments, breaks down his outlook heading into the new year. Garnder says that its reasonable for investors to be 'optimistic' about markets in 2026, expecting uncertainty around policy to die down. Gardner said that as tech trade narrows, there is opportunity for investors to diversify outside of the sector. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Snow Storm Brings Holiday Travel Disruptions to NYC Airports
summary: New York’s major airports have seen hundreds of flight cancellations as a significant winter storm descends on the city and neighboring regions. New York City is in line to get 5 to 9 inches (13 to 23 cm) of snow Friday into Saturday, according to the National Weather Service. Bill Wadell of AccuWeather has the details on Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: US Strikes ISIS in Cooperation With Nigeria
summary: The US launched a military strike against Islamic State targets in Nigeria in a security and intelligence collaboration with the African nation’s government. President Donald Trump said he directed American forces to carry out “a powerful and deadly strike” against ISIS. Laura Davison reports on Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)
